snippet.textDisplay:
while i expected the conclusion to be that it is the difference in games was going to be too small to notice, i am surprised that all the test subjects ended up thinking the sata one was fastest.

would have been interesting to see some more exotic setups such as optane, raid 0, ramdisk, some spinning rust, one of your fancy network drives. while im sure there would be some obvious differences (ramdisk + spinning rust i imagine should be obvious at at either end of the scale), raid 0/optane are more realistic options which it would be nice to see if they can be separated

as a final point, which this demonstrates that for these (and likely most) use cases going out and buying a fancy new pcie4 drive is pointless if you already have a fairly recent ssd, the price differences between sata and nvme if you are in the market for an ssd anyway i would go for nvme, im personally a fan of samsung 970 evo's and my only real decision is how much space i need :p
snippet.textOriginal:
while i expected the conclusion to be that it is the difference in games was going to be too small to notice, i am surprised that all the test subjects ended up thinking the sata one was fastest. 

would have been interesting to see some more exotic setups such as optane, raid 0, ramdisk, some spinning rust, one of your fancy network drives. while im sure there would be some obvious differences (ramdisk + spinning rust i imagine should be obvious at at either end of the scale), raid 0/optane are more realistic options which it would be nice to see if they can be separated 

as a final point, which this demonstrates that for these (and likely most) use cases going out and buying a fancy new pcie4 drive is pointless if you already have a fairly recent ssd, the price differences between sata and nvme if you are in the market for an ssd anyway i would go for nvme, im personally a fan of samsung 970 evo's and my only real decision is how much space i need :p

snippet.textDisplay: Moving from a SATA Samsung 850 to a 970 EVO has 8x faster theoretical sequential reads, but 2x (or less) faster theoretical random reads. That's not a huge difference in the "real world" over an entire 6 years of progress.

snippet.textDisplay:
Believe it or not, I skipped sata SSD all together.
My last PC was a Dell XPS L502x laptop with Sandy Bridge with a 500GB spinning 2.5" from 2011 or 2012.
I just recently built my first PC late 2019 and my only drive is a 1TB Sambrent Rocket NVMe.
After a full year of watching LTT, Gamers Nexus, Tech Deals, and Hardware Unboxed for PC building tips I went the NVMe route. Price difference between SATA and NVMe 1TB was very minor late 2019.
snippet.textOriginal:
Believe it or not, I skipped sata SSD all together.  
My last PC was a Dell XPS L502x laptop with Sandy Bridge with a 500GB spinning 2.5" from 2011 or 2012.  
I just recently built my first PC late 2019 and my only drive is a 1TB Sambrent Rocket NVMe.   
After a full year of watching LTT, Gamers Nexus, Tech Deals, and Hardware Unboxed for PC building tips I went the NVMe route.  Price difference between SATA and NVMe 1TB was very minor late 2019.

snippet.textDisplay: Well for me I did notice a difference between NVME and SATA. During map loading times on MHW, I would just button mash (to not waste time not having clicked "continue") knowing how quick it'd load. When I went to visit my friend and played MHW on his pc, I was actually expecting that it'd load as fast as mine like shown in this video so I went with my usual button mashing on map loading. But to my surprise, I stopped button-mashing since the map loading was taking longer than I thought it'd be and just went and stared at the slower loading screen.

In multiplayer racing sims also, I always seem to get spawned into the next track before anyone else.

snippet.textDisplay: Two words, dimishing returns. 4k IOPS matter most, and gen 4 SSDs you wont see a massive difference for gaming at all.
snippet.textOriginal: Two words, dimishing returns. 4k IOPS matter most, and gen 4 SSDs you wont see a massive difference for gaming at all.

snippet.textDisplay:
SSD speed really matters to some games and it doesn't matter that much for others.

Example, Path of Exile is a VERY SDD hungry game. Faster ssds means overall smoother transition to loading screens and better overall frame time.

Games like Doom though, where it only needs to load one big area and its done; it wont really matter that much for how fast your SSD is.

Thats my 2 cents on this matter.
snippet.textOriginal:
SSD speed really matters to some games and it doesn't matter that much for others.

Example, Path of Exile is a VERY SDD hungry game. Faster ssds means overall smoother transition to loading screens and better overall frame time. 

Games like Doom though, where it only needs to load one big area and its done; it wont really matter that much for how fast your SSD is. 

Thats my 2 cents on this matter.

snippet.textDisplay: I think everyone misjudging SATA as Gen4, its really simple. Gen4's bottlekneck is the chipset temps and NVME drive temps, now granted this test didnt show temps for either, but I would have to ask the question was this a factor for it being perceived as 'slower' while SATA (the slowest) was perceived as the fastest. I still dont trust how NVME's are very touchy to temperature changes, SATA for the win still imo.
snippet.textOriginal: I think everyone misjudging SATA as Gen4, its really simple. Gen4's bottlekneck is the chipset temps and NVME drive temps, now granted this test didnt show temps for either, but I would have to ask the question was this a factor for it being perceived as 'slower' while SATA (the slowest) was perceived as the fastest. I still dont trust how NVME's are very touchy to temperature changes, SATA for the win still imo.

snippet.textDisplay:
And then there's me sitting here with 2 gen 3's in Raid 0 for gaming. :/
It helps though when they get hot and start to slow down to have more than one. To dissipate heat better.
Also, the second best single upgrade you can do is your internet speed. It doesn't help to have a really fast CPU and storage solution if you're still only downloading your games at 1MB/sec.

snippet.textDisplay: When I first moved to an nvme drive it was really fast OS load times I noticed first, not as much as spinning rust to SSD, but still a big difference.  Also it should have been mentioned that a SATA SSD will be limited for anything with high IO because its having to interface using a command set for HDDs and PCIe bandwidth is way higher than SATA.  Appreciate that this was intended a real world.  Also, maybe having people test in different orders would have been eliminated the perception as get more picky issue you all discussed.
snippet.textOriginal: When I first moved to an nvme drive it was really fast OS load times I noticed first, not as much as spinning rust to SSD, but still a big difference. snippet.textDisplay:
For everyone worried about SSD longevity:
According to two tests that I found, the 250 GB Samsung 840 EVO managed between 900 and 1000 TB written before dying.
That's equivalent to nearly 4000 full writes. it had some errors along the way but overall surpassed expectations, just like the other SSDs that were tested.

The 250 GB 840 Pro went past 2400 TB easily, which is over 9600 full writes.

So yeah, don't worry about it. Your drives likely won't fail you anytime soon.



Sources:
http://www.nordichardware.se/SSD-Recensioner/vi-testar-livslaengden-pa-ssd-enheter-med-tlc-minne-foelj-vart-loepande-ssd-doedartest.html
https://techreport.com/review/27909/the-ssd-endurance-experiment-theyre-all-dead/
snippet.textOriginal:

The 250 GB 840 Pro went past 2400 TB easily, which is over 9600 full writes.

snippet.textDisplay:
The perceived differences might be down to the different storage drivers being used. The SATA system would be using the AHCI driver while the NVMe systems would be using the NVMe driver. Although in theory the NVMe driver should be superior by design, this might not necessarily be the case for all workload profiles unless proven otherwise. It could even be the storage controller on the SSD itself, since depending on vendor and tuning even two SATA drives with the same capacity could have vastly different performance profiles.

Would have been a good idea to include synthetic benchmark results for each of the systems, such as maximum I/O latency and speeds. This could have ruled out any anomalies like the SATA having lower latency which would possibly make a larger difference than higher transfer speeds.
snippet.textOriginal:
The perceived differences might be down to the different storage drivers being used. The SATA system would be using the AHCI driver while the NVMe systems would be using the NVMe driver. Although in theory the NVMe driver should be superior by design, this might not necessarily be the case for all workload profiles unless proven otherwise. It could even be the storage controller on the SSD itself, since depending on vendor and tuning even two SATA drives with the same capacity could have vastly different performance profiles.

Would have been a good idea to include synthetic benchmark results for each of the systems, such as maximum I/O latency and speeds. This could have ruled out any anomalies like the SATA having lower latency which would possibly make a larger difference than higher transfer speeds.

snippet.textDisplay: The biggest bang for the buck is going from spinning platters to 2.5 SSDs.  Do all your drives need to be SSD?  No.  Is M.2 NVMe significantly faster than 2.5" SSD?  If you measure in nanoseconds.  In everyday applications, NVMe is not necessary and does not appreciably contribute to a faster PC.  I have a mid-end 4x M.2, and I wouldn't buy it again... I'd rather put the $ from the NVMe price premium to a higher capacity 2.5" SSD.  Also, the sweet spot for the fastest SSDs is at least 1 TB.
snippet.textOriginal: The biggest bang for the buck is going from spinning platters to 2.5 SSDs.  Do all your drives need to be SSD?  No.  Is M.2 NVMe significantly faster than 2.5" SSD?  If you measure in nanoseconds.  In everyday applications, NVMe is not necessary and does not appreciably contribute to a faster PC.  I have a mid-end 4x M.2, and I wouldn't buy it again... I'd rather put the $ from the NVMe price premium to a higher capacity 2.5" SSD.  Also, the sweet spot for the fastest SSDs is at least 1 TB.

snippet.textDisplay: I recently switched from standard sata to NVMe in my new build and I really can't tell a difference in day to day things either. The only game I play that may show a benefit is Star Citizen, because of how the game streams in data, but since I don't have a side by side way to test, there's no telling. All I know is I now have more storage for cheaper, and don't have an extra component hanging around in my case. Both those are a win for me.
